column4: Sorry to poke you like that...But could you help? I'm running from LiveCD and would like to remove the linux-swap partition to recreate it at a second time. Can I do that without affecting my existing linux installation"

Because I have two partitions (one where my linux runs, one unallocated) and I'd like to extend my linux partition to use the unallocated space (through GParted). But in the middle there is the linux-swap partition
You could use the live CD and use gparted to do the partition changes and then edit the fstab file with the changed UUIDs.
So I was thinking, I'm going to remove the linux-swap partition, extend the linux partition, and then re-create the linux-swap. Can I do that?
Dont lower the swap size lower than the installed physical ram.
I was thinking of setting it up as double the size of my RAM
You can. Thats a little big but will do just fine.
You also said that I should edit /etc/fstab? Just by adding the newly-created linux-swap partition?
If you change existing partition layout then Im pretty sure the UUID will change for the swap partition and maybe any that you resize but Im not sure how exactly what the criteria are for that.
But you want to double check. If any of the partitions mentioned in fstab are wrong such as the root partition then you wont be booting on restart.
Now I have my linux partition and some unallocated space, but GParted will not allow me to extend the linux partition using the unallocated space. Is there anything I should do first?
The empty space need to be directly to the right of whateer partition you want to extend.
Geez, it's on the left, what can I do now?
Make sure you know how to edit the fstab or your gonna screw your install.
